item.title: 10 Ways to Spot an Exceptional Employee
item.description:
10 Ways to Spot an Exceptional Employee

We're searching for top company cultures to be featured on our annual list. Think your company has what it takes? Apply Now " A recent international study surveyed more than 500 business leaders and asked them what sets great employees apart.

item.title: 5 Leadership Behaviors You Want in a High Potential Employee
item.description:
5 Leadership Behaviors You Want in a High Potential Employee

In 2014, the University of North Carolina's Kenan-Flager Business School, in partnership with Human Capital Institute (HCI), conducted a study where they found that 85 percent of global companies report an urgent need to develop employees with leadership potential.

item.title: 15 Business Tips Every Entrepreneur Should Know
item.description:
15 Business Tips Every Entrepreneur Should Know

We're searching for top company cultures to be featured on our annual list. Think your company has what it takes? Apply Now " The biggest problem founders and small business owners have is that they're experts in their field and novices in what it really takes to effectively run a business.

item.title: 8 Ways Smart People Use Failure To Their Advantage
item.description:
8 Ways Smart People Use Failure To Their Advantage

Failure is an inevitable part of life, but smart people know how to make it work for them. Learn how to use failure to propel you forward.

item.title: Steve Jobs: don't start a business unless there's 'a wrong that you want to right'
item.description:
Steve Jobs: don't start a business unless there's 'a wrong that you want to right'

As the funding climate in Silicon Valley cools, a lot of old-timers are looking on the bright side: at least this will wash out the startup founders who were only ever in it for the money - the "tourists" as Alfred Lin from Sequoia calls them.

item.title: Why Tesla Will Destroy the Automobile Industry
item.description:
Why Tesla Will Destroy the Automobile Industry

If there's an example of a company about to disruptively innovate an entire industry, it's Tesla. Partly, this is because of raw technology--Tesla's is clearly superior to that of its competitors. Partly, it's because Tesla has a more efficient business model. As Slate recently pointed out, Tesla bypasses value-subtracting dealer franchises and universally disliked car salespeople.
